name: Breast
description: The mammary gland is a modified apocrine sweat gland composed of 15-20 lobes of tubuloalveolar glands embedded in adipose and connective tissue. Its structure varies with age, menstrual cycle, and pregnancy.

features: Lobes of tubuloalveolar glands separated by interlobar connective tissue
Lactiferous ducts (15-20) open at nipple
Two types of epithelium: luminal secretory and basal myoepithelial cells
Intralobular stroma: loose, hormone-responsive connective tissue
Interlobular stroma: dense fibrous connective tissue with adipose
location: Anterior chest wall overlying pectoralis major
Extends from 2nd to 6th rib, sternum to midaxillary line
Axillary tail of Spence extends toward axilla
function: Milk production and secretion during lactation
Myoepithelial cells contract to expel milk
Secondary sexual characteristic
theory.examTips: Breast lymphatic drainage: 75% to axillary nodes (most important for cancer spread). Remember the two cell layers: inner luminal cells (secretory) and outer myoepithelial cells (contractile, tumor suppressors). Cooper's ligaments provide structural support.

name: Atrioventricular valve
description: The AV valves (mitral and tricuspid) are composed of dense fibrous connective tissue covered by endothelium. They prevent backflow of blood from ventricles to atria during systole.

features: Core of dense irregular connective tissue (fibrosa)
Covered on both surfaces by endothelium
Avascular structure - nutrients from blood bathing surfaces
Spongiosa layer contains loose connective tissue with proteoglycans
Attachment to fibrous annulus of heart skeleton
location: Between atria and ventricles
Mitral (bicuspid) valve - left side
Tricuspid valve - right side
function: Prevents regurgitation of blood during ventricular systole
Ensures unidirectional blood flow through heart
theory.examTips: AV valves are avascular and lack blood vessels, lymphatics, and nerves. The mitral valve has 2 cusps while tricuspid has 3. Remember: 'Left = Less (cusps)'

name: Chordae Tendinae
description: Chordae tendinae are fibrous string-like structures connecting free edges of AV valve cusps to papillary muscles. They are composed of dense collagenous tissue covered by endothelium.

features: Cord-like structures of dense regular collagenous tissue
Covered by thin layer of endocardium
Central core contains parallel collagen fibers
May contain elastic fibers near attachment points
Avascular - no blood vessels within
location: Extend from papillary muscles to free margins of AV valve cusps
Present in both left and right ventricles
function: Prevent eversion/prolapse of valve cusps during ventricular systole
Transmit tension from papillary muscles to valve leaflets
Maintain valve competence during high pressure
theory.examTips: Chordae tendinae + papillary muscles = subvalvular apparatus. Rupture of chordae leads to acute mitral/tricuspid regurgitation - a surgical emergency!

name: Aorta
description: The aorta is the largest elastic artery in the body. Its wall is characterized by multiple concentric layers of elastic lamellae in the tunica media, allowing it to withstand and dampen pulsatile blood flow.

features: Thick wall with 3 layers: intima, media, adventitia
40-70 concentric elastic lamellae in tunica media (fenestrated sheets)
Smooth muscle cells between elastic lamellae
Vasa vasorum in outer adventitia and outer media
Internal elastic lamina may be indistinct due to abundant elastic tissue
location: Arises from left ventricle at aortic valve
Ascending aorta → Aortic arch → Descending (thoracic & abdominal) aorta
function: Conducts oxygenated blood from heart to systemic circulation
Windkessel effect - dampens pulsatile flow to continuous flow
Elastic recoil maintains diastolic blood pressure
theory.examTips: Elastic arteries = conducting arteries. The aorta has the most elastic lamellae. Vasa vasorum supply outer 2/3 of media; inner 1/3 is nourished by luminal diffusion.

name: Aorta- Tunica Adventitia
description: The tunica adventitia is the outermost layer of the aorta, composed of loose connective tissue containing vasa vasorum, nervi vasorum, and lymphatic vessels.

features: Loose connective tissue with collagen and elastic fibers
Contains vasa vasorum (small arteries supplying vessel wall)
Nervi vasorum (autonomic nerve fibers) present
Lymphatic vessels for drainage
Fibroblasts are the predominant cell type
location: Outermost layer of aorta
Merges with surrounding connective tissue
function: Provides nutrition to outer layers of vessel wall via vasa vasorum
Anchors vessel to surrounding tissues
Contains autonomic nerves regulating vessel tone
theory.examTips: External elastic lamina is absent or poorly defined in elastic arteries like aorta. Vasa vasorum are more prominent in veins than arteries due to thinner walls and lower oxygen tension.

name: Aorta- Tunica Media
description: The tunica media of the aorta is the thickest layer, dominated by concentrically arranged elastic lamellae with smooth muscle cells and extracellular matrix between them.

features: 40-70 fenestrated elastic lamellae arranged concentrically
Smooth muscle cells (SMCs) between lamellae
Ground substance rich in proteoglycans
Collagen fibers interspersed between elastic layers
Inner portion avascular; outer portion has vasa vasorum
location: Middle layer of aortic wall
Between tunica intima and adventitia
function: Elastic recoil converts pulsatile to continuous flow
SMCs produce and maintain extracellular matrix
Provides structural integrity to vessel wall
theory.examTips: In elastic arteries, tunica media is the thickest layer. The elastic lamellae appear wavy in histological sections. Marfan syndrome involves defective fibrillin-1 causing aortic dissection.

name: Coronary Artery
description: Coronary arteries are muscular arteries that supply the myocardium. They have a prominent tunica media with smooth muscle and distinct internal elastic lamina.

features: Muscular (medium-sized) artery with thick tunica media
Prominent internal elastic lamina (appears wavy)
Tunica media composed mainly of smooth muscle cells
External elastic lamina may be present
Located in epicardial fat in coronary sulci
location: Left coronary artery: anterior interventricular (LAD) and circumflex branches
Right coronary artery: supplies right heart and posterior descending artery (in 70%)
Travel in subepicardial connective tissue
function: Supply oxygenated blood to myocardium
Regulate blood flow via vasoconstriction/vasodilation
Perfusion occurs mainly during diastole
theory.examTips: Coronary arteries are functional end arteries - occlusion leads to infarction. LAD is 'widow maker'. Coronary blood flow occurs during diastole because myocardial contraction compresses vessels during systole.

name: Coronary Vein
description: Coronary veins drain deoxygenated blood from myocardium into the coronary sinus. They have thinner walls than arteries with less distinct layers and may contain valves.

features: Thin-walled compared to accompanying coronary arteries
Less smooth muscle in tunica media
May contain valves (endothelial folds)
Larger lumen relative to wall thickness
Three layers less distinct than in arteries
location: Great cardiac vein → follows LAD
Middle cardiac vein → follows posterior interventricular artery
Drain into coronary sinus → right atrium
function: Drain deoxygenated blood from myocardium
Coronary sinus is the main venous drainage route (60%)
Thebesian veins drain directly into cardiac chambers
theory.examTips: Coronary sinus receives great, middle, and small cardiac veins. It opens into the right atrium between the IVC opening and tricuspid valve. Thebesian veins contribute to physiological shunting.

name: Endocardium
description: The endocardium is the innermost layer of the heart wall, lining the chambers and covering the valves. It consists of endothelium, subendothelial connective tissue, and a deeper subendocardial layer.

features: Endothelium: simple squamous epithelium (continuous with blood vessels)
Subendothelial layer: thin connective tissue with collagen and elastic fibers
Subendocardial layer: loose connective tissue with Purkinje fibers
Contains small blood vessels and nerves
Thicker in atria than ventricles
location: Lines all four cardiac chambers
Continuous with tunica intima of great vessels
Forms the surface of cardiac valves
function: Provides smooth, non-thrombogenic surface for blood flow
Subendocardial layer contains conducting system (Purkinje fibers)
Secretes endothelin, NO, and other vasoactive substances
theory.examTips: Purkinje fibers are in the subendocardial layer - they appear pale with central nuclei and abundant glycogen. Endocardium is thickest in left atrium and thinnest in left ventricle.

name: Epicardium
description: The epicardium (visceral pericardium) is the outermost layer of the heart wall, composed of mesothelium and underlying connective tissue containing coronary vessels, nerves, and adipose tissue.

features: Mesothelium: simple squamous epithelium on outer surface
Subepicardial layer: loose connective tissue with adipose
Contains coronary arteries, veins, and lymphatics
Autonomic nerve fibers and ganglia present
Adipose tissue prominent in coronary sulci
location: Outer surface of heart (visceral layer of serous pericardium)
Continuous with parietal pericardium at great vessel roots
Covers entire heart except area of great vessel attachments
function: Secretes serous fluid for frictionless heart movement
Contains and protects coronary vasculature
Participates in inflammatory responses (pericarditis)
theory.examTips: Epicardium = visceral pericardium. The pericardial cavity is between visceral and parietal layers. Epicardial fat accumulates with age and obesity - correlates with coronary artery disease.

name: Myocardium
description: The myocardium is the thick middle layer of the heart wall composed of cardiac muscle fibers (cardiomyocytes) arranged in complex spiraling patterns, responsible for cardiac contraction.

features: Cardiac muscle fibers: branched, striated, uninucleate/binucleate cells
Intercalated discs: specialized junctions (desmosomes, fascia adherens, gap junctions)
Central nucleus (unlike peripheral nuclei in skeletal muscle)
Abundant mitochondria (30-40% of cell volume)
Rich capillary network (1 capillary per myocyte)
location: Middle layer of heart wall between endocardium and epicardium
Thickest in left ventricle (10-15mm), thinnest in atria (2mm)
function: Generates contractile force for blood pumping
Gap junctions allow rapid electrical impulse spread
Functions as a syncytium (coordinated contraction)
theory.examTips: Intercalated discs are KEY identification feature of cardiac muscle. They appear as dark lines perpendicular to fiber direction. Gap junctions provide electrical coupling - damage leads to arrhythmias.

name: Normal Heart
description: The normal heart wall shows three distinct layers: endocardium (innermost), myocardium (thickest, muscular middle layer), and epicardium (outermost). The cardiac skeleton provides structural support.

features: Three layers visible: endocardium, myocardium, epicardium
Cardiac muscle fibers with intercalated discs
Cardiac skeleton (fibrous rings around valves)
Conducting system: SA node, AV node, bundle of His, Purkinje fibers
Rich vasculature from coronary arteries
location: Mediastinum between lungs
Apex pointing left and inferiorly
Base formed by atria posteriorly
function: Pumps blood through pulmonary and systemic circuits
Atria: receiving chambers; Ventricles: pumping chambers
Right heart: pulmonary circulation; Left heart: systemic circulation
theory.examTips: Left ventricle wall is 3x thicker than right ventricle (higher pressure). Cardiac skeleton provides: valve attachment, electrical insulation between atria and ventricles, and structural support.

name: Cerebellar Cortex
description: The cerebellar cortex has three distinct layers: outer molecular layer, middle Purkinje cell layer, and inner granular layer. The Purkinje cells are the hallmark of cerebellar histology.

features: Three-layered cortex: molecular, Purkinje, granular (outer to inner)
Purkinje cells: large flask-shaped neurons with extensive dendritic trees
Molecular layer: mostly neuropil with few cells (basket and stellate cells)
Granular layer: densely packed small granule cells (most numerous neurons in brain)
Cerebellar glomeruli: synaptic complexes in granular layer
location: Posterior cranial fossa, beneath tentorium cerebelli
Attached to brainstem via three cerebellar peduncles
function: Motor coordination and balance
Purkinje cells provide sole output of cerebellar cortex (inhibitory)
Processing of proprioceptive information
theory.examTips: Purkinje cells are KEY identification feature - large, flask-shaped with prominent nucleolus. Only GABAergic output. Granular layer appears basophilic due to densely packed nuclei. Damage causes ataxia and intention tremor.

name: Cerebellum
description: The cerebellum shows characteristic folia (folds) with a branching white matter core (arbor vitae) covered by three-layered gray matter cortex. It coordinates movement and maintains posture.

features: Folia: narrow, parallel folds of cerebellar surface
Arbor vitae: tree-like branching white matter
Gray matter covers white matter (opposite of cerebrum arrangement)
Deep cerebellar nuclei embedded in white matter
Pia mater follows contour of folia
location: Posterior cranial fossa
Connected to pons, medulla, and midbrain via peduncles
Separated from cerebrum by tentorium cerebelli
function: Coordination of voluntary movements
Maintenance of balance and posture
Motor learning and procedural memory
theory.examTips: Arbor vitae = 'tree of life' - named for branching white matter pattern. Three lobes: anterior, posterior, flocculonodular. Flocculonodular lobe connects to vestibular system (balance). Vermian lesions cause truncal ataxia.

name: Cerebral Cortex
description: The cerebral cortex is organized into 6 layers of gray matter containing pyramidal neurons, stellate cells, and abundant neuropil. The neocortex follows this 6-layer pattern.

features: Six histological layers (I-VI from surface to white matter)
Layer I (molecular): few cells, mainly dendrites and axons
Layer III & V: pyramidal neurons (output neurons)
Layer IV: granule cells (input layer, receives thalamic fibers)
Neurons, glial cells, and blood vessels in neuropil
location: Surface of cerebral hemispheres (gray matter covers white matter)
Organized into gyri (ridges) and sulci (grooves)
Thickness varies: 1.5-4.5mm depending on region
function: Higher cognitive functions: thought, perception, consciousness
Motor planning and execution (layer V pyramidal neurons)
Sensory processing (layer IV receives input)
theory.examTips: 6 layers characterize neocortex (90% of cortex). Motor cortex has thick layer V with giant Betz cells. Sensory cortex has thick layer IV. Remember: 'I-Molecular, II-External granular, III-External pyramidal, IV-Internal granular, V-Internal pyramidal, VI-Multiform'

name: Cerebrum
description: The cerebrum is the largest brain region with two hemispheres connected by corpus callosum. It shows outer gray matter cortex, underlying white matter, and deep gray matter nuclei (basal ganglia).

features: Gyri and sulci increase surface area for neurons
Gray matter (cortex) covers white matter
White matter contains myelinated axons (fibers)
Basal ganglia: deep gray matter nuclei (caudate, putamen, globus pallidus)
Lateral ventricles within each hemisphere
location: Largest part of brain, fills most of cranium
Two hemispheres in anterior and middle cranial fossae
Connected by corpus callosum (largest commissure)
function: Seat of consciousness, cognition, and voluntary movement
Sensory perception and interpretation
Memory, emotion, and higher executive functions
theory.examTips: Cerebrum has gray matter externally, white matter internally (opposite of spinal cord). Key regions: frontal (motor, personality), parietal (sensory), temporal (hearing, memory), occipital (vision). Broca's and Wernicke's areas for speech.

name: White Matter
description: White matter consists of myelinated axons bundled into tracts. The white appearance is due to lipid-rich myelin sheaths produced by oligodendrocytes.

features: Myelinated axon bundles (nerve fiber tracts)
Oligodendrocytes produce myelin (one cell myelinates multiple axons)
Microglia, astrocytes, and blood vessels present
Association fibers: connect same hemisphere areas
Commissural fibers: connect both hemispheres (corpus callosum)
location: Deep to cerebral cortex
Centrum semiovale: large white matter mass of hemispheres
Internal capsule: between basal ganglia and thalamus
function: Rapid conduction of nerve impulses
Connects different brain regions
Three fiber types: association, commissural, projection
theory.examTips: Oligodendrocytes are the myelin-forming cells of CNS (vs Schwann cells in PNS). Multiple sclerosis involves demyelination of white matter. Internal capsule lesions cause contralateral hemiparesis. LFB stain highlights myelin.

name: Dentate Gyrus
description: The dentate gyrus is a C-shaped structure within the hippocampal formation containing densely packed granule cells. It is a major site of adult neurogenesis and plays a role in memory formation.

features: Three layers: molecular, granule cell, polymorphic (hilus)
Granule cells: small, densely packed neurons in granule layer
Mossy fibers: axons of granule cells project to CA3
Subgranular zone: site of adult neurogenesis
C-shaped or V-shaped configuration embracing CA3
location: Medial temporal lobe as part of hippocampal formation
Interlocks with hippocampus proper (Ammon's horn)
Part of limbic system
function: Pattern separation in memory processing
Adult neurogenesis - new neurons throughout life
Part of the trisynaptic circuit of hippocampus
theory.examTips: Dentate gyrus is one of two brain regions with adult neurogenesis (other is subventricular zone). Granule cells send mossy fibers to CA3 pyramidal neurons. Damage affects spatial memory and pattern separation.

name: Hippocampus
description: The hippocampus (Ammon's horn) is a curved structure with three-layered archicortex divided into CA1-CA4 regions. It is critical for memory consolidation and spatial navigation.

features: Three-layered archicortex (simpler than 6-layer neocortex)
CA regions: CA1, CA2, CA3, CA4 (pyramidal neurons vary in size)
Pyramidal cell layer: large neurons in characteristic curved arrangement
Stratum oriens, pyramidale, radiatum, lacunosum-moleculare
Alveus: white matter covering hippocampal surface
location: Medial temporal lobe, floor of lateral ventricle temporal horn
Part of limbic system
Bilateral - one in each hemisphere
function: Consolidation of short-term to long-term memory
Spatial memory and navigation
Episodic memory formation
theory.examTips: CA1 neurons are most vulnerable to hypoxic injury (watershed zone). Hippocampus is involved in Alzheimer's disease (early atrophy). Bilateral damage causes anterograde amnesia (like patient H.M.). Papez circuit involves hippocampus.

name: M.O. (Inferior Olivary Nucleus)
description: The inferior olivary nucleus is a prominent convoluted structure in the medulla. It appears as a crumpled bag or bag of cells and is a major relay station for cerebellar afferents.

features: Distinctive crinkled/folded appearance (like a crumpled bag)
Contains principal olive and accessory olivary nuclei
Large neurons arranged in convolutions
Surrounded by white matter tracts
Hilum faces medially toward midline
location: Anterolateral medulla oblongata
Forms olive bulge on external medullary surface
Between pyramids and inferior cerebellar peduncle
function: Source of climbing fibers to cerebellar cortex
Motor learning and timing
Receives input from motor cortex, basal ganglia, red nucleus
theory.examTips: Inferior olive sends climbing fibers to Purkinje cells via inferior cerebellar peduncle. Each climbing fiber synapses on one Purkinje cell (unlike parallel fibers). Involved in motor learning and timing. Lesions cause tremor.

name: Medulla Oblongata
description: The medulla oblongata is the caudal part of brainstem connecting to spinal cord. It contains vital autonomic centers and shows characteristic structures like pyramids, olives, and cranial nerve nuclei.

features: Pyramids: ventral white matter (corticospinal tracts)
Pyramidal decussation at caudal end
Olives: lateral bulges containing olivary nuclei
Cranial nerve nuclei: IX, X, XI, XII
Gracile and cuneate nuclei dorsally
location: Between pons (rostrally) and spinal cord (caudally)
At foramen magnum level
Forms lower part of floor of 4th ventricle
function: Vital centers: cardiac, respiratory, vasomotor
Decussation of major motor and sensory tracts
Reflex centers for vomiting, coughing, swallowing
theory.examTips: Medulla contains life-sustaining centers - injury can be fatal. Lateral medullary syndrome (PICA stroke) causes crossed sensory loss. Pyramidal decussation explains contralateral motor control. Lower cranial nerves (IX-XII) originate here.

name: Midbrain
description: The midbrain (mesencephalon) is the shortest brainstem segment, characterized by cerebral peduncles ventrally, tegmentum, and tectum (superior and inferior colliculi) dorsally. The cerebral aqueduct passes through it.

features: Cerebral peduncles: large ventral fiber bundles (corticospinal/bulbar tracts)
Tectum: superior colliculi (visual) and inferior colliculi (auditory)
Cerebral aqueduct: connects 3rd and 4th ventricles
Substantia nigra: dark pigmented nucleus (dopaminergic)
Red nucleus: reddish due to iron content
location: Between pons (caudally) and diencephalon (rostrally)
Passes through tentorial notch
Shortest part of brainstem
function: Visual and auditory reflexes (tectum)
Motor control pathways (cerebral peduncles)
Dopamine production (substantia nigra)
theory.examTips: Midbrain lesions: Weber syndrome (CN III + contralateral hemiparesis) and Benedikt syndrome (CN III + contralateral tremor). Parinaud syndrome involves superior colliculus. Aqueductal stenosis causes hydrocephalus.

name: Substantia Nigra
description: The substantia nigra is a darkly pigmented nucleus in the midbrain due to neuromelanin in dopaminergic neurons. It has two parts: pars compacta (dopaminergic) and pars reticulata (GABAergic).

features: Dark pigmentation due to neuromelanin (dopamine metabolite)
Pars compacta (SNpc): dopaminergic neurons, dorsal
Pars reticulata (SNpr): GABAergic neurons, ventral
Located between cerebral peduncles and tegmentum
Neurons contain abundant melanin pigment granules
location: Midbrain, between crus cerebri and tegmentum
Extends through length of midbrain
Forms part of basal ganglia functionally
function: Dopamine release to striatum (nigrostriatal pathway)
Motor planning and movement initiation
Part of reward and addiction circuits
theory.examTips: Degeneration of SNpc dopaminergic neurons causes Parkinson's disease (TRAP: Tremor, Rigidity, Akinesia, Postural instability). Neuromelanin increases with age. Lewy bodies are pathological hallmark of Parkinson's.

name: Anterior Pituitary
description: The anterior pituitary (adenohypophysis) is glandular tissue derived from oral ectoderm (Rathke's pouch). It contains cords of epithelial cells that produce trophic hormones under hypothalamic control.

features: Cords and clusters of epithelial cells with rich sinusoidal capillaries
Three cell types by staining: acidophils, basophils, chromophobes
Acidophils: somatotrophs (GH) and lactotrophs (prolactin)
Basophils: corticotrophs (ACTH), thyrotrophs (TSH), gonadotrophs (FSH/LH)
Chromophobes: degranulated or undifferentiated cells
location: Anterior part of sella turcica (hypophyseal fossa)
Derived from Rathke's pouch (oral ectoderm)
Larger than posterior pituitary (~75% of gland)
function: Secretes 6 major hormones: GH, prolactin, ACTH, TSH, FSH, LH
Regulated by hypothalamic releasing/inhibiting hormones
Hormones reach target organs via systemic circulation
theory.examTips: Remember 'FLAT PEG' for anterior pituitary hormones: FSH, LH, ACTH, TSH, Prolactin, Endorphins, GH. Acidophils are GH + Prolactin (growth and lactation). Pituitary adenomas are most commonly prolactinomas.

name: Pars Intermedia
description: The pars intermedia is a thin zone between anterior and posterior pituitary, containing basophilic cells and colloid-filled cysts (Rathke's cysts). It is rudimentary in humans but prominent in other animals.

features: Thin layer of basophilic cells
Colloid-filled cysts (remnants of Rathke's pouch)
Contains POMC-producing cells (like corticotrophs)
Relatively avascular compared to pars distalis
May contain melanotrophs in some species
location: Between pars distalis (anterior) and pars nervosa (posterior)
Surrounds residual lumen of Rathke's pouch
Very thin in adult humans
function: Produces MSH (melanocyte-stimulating hormone) - minor in humans
POMC processing
Rudimentary role in human physiology
theory.examTips: Rathke's pouch remnants can form Rathke's cleft cysts or craniopharyngiomas. Pars intermedia is vestigial in humans but prominent in lower vertebrates. MSH causes skin darkening - important in amphibians, not humans.

name: Pituitary Gland
description: The pituitary gland (hypophysis) is a pea-sized master endocrine gland with two distinct parts: anterior (glandular adenohypophysis) and posterior (neural neurohypophysis), each with different embryological origins.

features: Two embryologically distinct parts: adenohypophysis and neurohypophysis
Adenohypophysis: glandular epithelium from Rathke's pouch
Neurohypophysis: neural tissue from diencephalon
Connected to hypothalamus via pituitary stalk
Hypophyseal portal system connects hypothalamus to anterior pituitary
location: Sella turcica of sphenoid bone
Below optic chiasm (important for visual field defects)
Connected to hypothalamus by infundibulum
function: Master endocrine gland - regulates other glands
Anterior: synthesizes and secretes hormones
Posterior: stores and releases hypothalamic hormones (ADH, oxytocin)
theory.examTips: Pituitary tumor expanding upward compresses optic chiasm causing bitemporal hemianopia. Sheehan syndrome: postpartum pituitary necrosis from hemorrhage. Empty sella syndrome: CSF fills sella, compressing pituitary.

name: Pituitary Stalk
description: The pituitary stalk (infundibulum) connects the hypothalamus to the pituitary gland. It contains axons from hypothalamic nuclei and the hypophyseal portal vessels.

features: Contains hypothalamo-hypophyseal tract axons
Hypophyseal portal vessels run along its surface
Pars tuberalis wraps around the stalk
Unmyelinated axons from supraoptic and paraventricular nuclei
Pituicytes (glial cells) present
location: Connects median eminence of hypothalamus to pituitary
Passes through diaphragma sellae
Posterior to optic chiasm
function: Carries axons transporting ADH and oxytocin to posterior pituitary
Portal vessels carry releasing hormones to anterior pituitary
Physical and vascular connection between hypothalamus and pituitary
theory.examTips: Stalk transection causes diabetes insipidus (loss of ADH) and hyperprolactinemia (loss of dopamine inhibition). Hypophyseal portal system is KEY for anterior pituitary regulation - no direct neural control.

name: Posterior Pituitary
description: The posterior pituitary (neurohypophysis) is neural tissue derived from the diencephalon. It stores and releases ADH and oxytocin synthesized in hypothalamic nuclei, transported via axons.

features: Composed of unmyelinated axons and pituicytes (glial cells)
Herring bodies: axonal dilations storing hormones
No epithelial cells - purely neural tissue
Rich capillary network for hormone release
Axon terminals from supraoptic and paraventricular nuclei
location: Posterior part of pituitary gland in sella turcica
Derived from floor of diencephalon (neural ectoderm)
Continuous with infundibulum
function: Stores and releases ADH (from supraoptic nucleus)
Stores and releases oxytocin (from paraventricular nucleus)
No hormone synthesis - only storage and release
theory.examTips: Posterior pituitary does NOT synthesize hormones - they're made in hypothalamus. Herring bodies are KEY identification feature - eosinophilic axonal swellings. Diabetes insipidus results from ADH deficiency. Oxytocin: milk ejection and uterine contraction.

name: Basal Pons
description: The basal pons (basis pontis) is the ventral portion containing transverse pontine fibers, longitudinal corticospinal tracts, and scattered pontine nuclei. It forms the characteristic bulge of the pons.

features: Transverse pontine fibers: form middle cerebellar peduncle
Longitudinal fascicles: corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts
Pontine nuclei: scattered gray matter masses
Complex interlacing of fibers and nuclei
Clear demarcation from tegmentum dorsally
location: Ventral (anterior) part of pons
Between midbrain and medulla
Anterior to 4th ventricle
function: Relay station between cerebral cortex and cerebellum
Conducts motor tracts to spinal cord
Integration of motor signals
theory.examTips: Basal pons lesions: 'locked-in syndrome' if bilateral - consciousness preserved but only vertical eye movements possible. Pontine nuclei relay cortical motor info to cerebellum via middle cerebellar peduncle. Central pontine myelinolysis from rapid sodium correction.

name: Pons
description: The pons is the middle brainstem segment with ventral basis pontis and dorsal tegmentum. It contains cranial nerve nuclei (V-VIII), respiratory centers, and connects cerebrum to cerebellum.

features: Two main parts: basis pontis (ventral) and tegmentum (dorsal)
Cranial nerve nuclei: trigeminal (V), abducens (VI), facial (VII), vestibulocochlear (VIII)
Pneumotaxic and apneustic centers for respiration
Floor of 4th ventricle dorsally
Middle cerebellar peduncles connect to cerebellum
location: Between midbrain (rostral) and medulla (caudal)
Bulges anteriorly - appears convex
Forms upper part of 4th ventricle floor
function: Relay between cortex and cerebellum
Cranial nerve functions: facial sensation, expression, hearing, balance
Respiratory rhythm modulation
theory.examTips: Pons houses CN V-VIII nuclei. Remember: 'At Pons (5-8)'. Facial colliculus on 4th ventricle floor contains abducens nucleus with facial nerve fibers looping around it. Lesions cause gaze palsy + facial weakness.

name: Spinal Cord
description: The spinal cord shows characteristic H-shaped or butterfly-shaped gray matter surrounded by white matter. It extends from foramen magnum to L1-L2 vertebral level as the conus medullaris.

features: Gray matter centrally: H-shaped with anterior and posterior horns
White matter peripherally: organized into columns (funiculi)
Central canal lined by ependymal cells
31 spinal segments: 8 cervical, 12 thoracic, 5 lumbar, 5 sacral, 1 coccygeal
Surrounded by meninges: pia, arachnoid, dura mater
location: Vertebral canal from foramen magnum to L1-L2
Conus medullaris: tapered end at L1-L2
Cauda equina: nerve roots below conus
function: Conducts sensory and motor information
Contains reflex arcs
Lower motor neurons in anterior horn
theory.examTips: Spinal cord has gray matter internally, white matter externally (opposite of brain). Ends at L1-L2 in adults (L3 in newborns). Lumbar puncture done below L3 to avoid cord injury. Cervical and lumbar enlargements for limb innervation.

name: Spinal Cord (Central Canal)
description: The central canal is a narrow channel in the center of spinal cord gray matter, lined by ependymal cells. It is continuous with the ventricular system and contains cerebrospinal fluid.

features: Lined by simple columnar/cuboidal ependymal cells
Located in gray commissure between anterior horns
May be obliterated in adults
Continuous with 4th ventricle superiorly
Surrounded by substantia gelatinosa centralis
location: Center of spinal cord gray matter
Within gray commissure at level of crossbar of 'H'
Extends full length of spinal cord
function: Circulation of cerebrospinal fluid
Remnant of neural tube lumen
May enlarge in syringomyelia
theory.examTips: Central canal is remnant of embryonic neural tube cavity. Syringomyelia: abnormal cavity near/in central canal - causes 'cape-like' sensory loss (pain and temperature in upper limbs) due to damage to crossing spinothalamic fibers.

name: Spinal Cord (Cervical Enlargement)
description: The cervical enlargement (C4-T1) is a widening of spinal cord that contains increased gray matter for brachial plexus neurons innervating the upper limbs.

features: Enlarged diameter compared to other cord levels
Larger anterior horns with more motor neurons
More gray matter relative to white matter
Oval or elliptical cross-sectional shape
Contains neurons for brachial plexus (C5-T1)
location: C4 to T1 vertebral levels
Upper spinal cord
Corresponds to upper limb innervation
function: Motor and sensory innervation of upper limbs
Contains lower motor neurons for arm and hand muscles
Sensory processing from upper limbs
theory.examTips: Two enlargements: cervical (C4-T1 for upper limb) and lumbar (L1-S3 for lower limb). Brachial plexus injuries affect cervical enlargement neurons. Polio preferentially affects anterior horn cells here causing upper limb paralysis.

name: Spinal Cord (Dorsal Column)
description: The dorsal columns (posterior funiculi) are white matter tracts carrying fine touch, vibration, and proprioception. They consist of fasciculus gracilis (medial) and fasciculus cuneatus (lateral, above T6).

features: Fasciculus gracilis: lower limb sensory fibers (medial)
Fasciculus cuneatus: upper limb sensory fibers (lateral, above T6)
First-order neurons with cell bodies in dorsal root ganglia
Myelinated ascending fibers
Separated by posterior intermediate sulcus (above T6)
location: Posterior white matter between posterior horns
Bounded by posterior median sulcus and dorsolateral sulcus
Synapse in brainstem nuclei (gracilis and cuneatus)
function: Fine/discriminative touch sensation
Proprioception (position sense)
Vibration sense
theory.examTips: Dorsal column lesion = loss of ipsilateral fine touch, vibration, proprioception below lesion. Remember: 'DCML pathway' - Dorsal Column, Medial Lemniscus. Gracilis = legs (G for gracile, G for ground). Tabes dorsalis (syphilis) affects dorsal columns.

name: Spinal Cord (Dorsolateral Sulcus)
description: The dorsolateral sulcus is a groove on the posterolateral surface of spinal cord where dorsal (sensory) nerve roots enter. It marks the boundary between posterior and lateral funiculi.

features: Shallow groove on posterolateral spinal cord surface
Entry point for dorsal root fibers (sensory)
Boundary between posterior and lateral white columns
Continuous along entire cord length
Corresponds to attachment of dorsal rootlets
location: Posterolateral surface of spinal cord
Between posterior funiculus and lateral funiculus
Paired - one on each side
function: Entry zone for primary sensory afferents
Anatomical landmark for cord orientation
Surgical landmark for dorsal root entry zone procedures
theory.examTips: Dorsolateral sulcus = sensory nerve entry (dorsal root). Compare to anterolateral sulcus = motor nerve exit (ventral root). Remember: 'Dorsal = sensory, Ventral = motor' (Bell-Magendie law). DREZ lesions done here for pain relief.

name: Ventral horns
description: The ventral (anterior) horns contain large multipolar lower motor neurons (alpha and gamma) that innervate skeletal muscles. They are larger at cervical and lumbar enlargements.

features: Large multipolar alpha motor neurons (lower motor neurons)
Smaller gamma motor neurons for muscle spindles
Organized somatotopically: medial = axial, lateral = limb muscles
Abundant Nissl substance in motor neurons
More prominent in cervical and lumbar enlargements
location: Anterior portion of spinal cord gray matter
Contains cell bodies of LMNs for skeletal muscle
Surrounded by interneurons and glia
function: Lower motor neuron cell bodies for voluntary movement
Alpha neurons innervate extrafusal muscle fibers
Gamma neurons innervate intrafusal muscle spindle fibers
theory.examTips: Anterior horn cell damage = LMN signs (weakness, atrophy, fasciculations, hyporeflexia, hypotonia). Polio and ALS affect anterior horn cells. Somatotopic organization: medial neurons = trunk/proximal, lateral neurons = distal limb muscles.

name: Ventral Horns (LFB Stains)
description: Luxol fast blue (LFB) stain highlights myelin in spinal cord sections. White matter stains blue while gray matter appears lighter, clearly demonstrating the distribution of myelinated fibers.

features: LFB stains myelin phospholipids blue/green
White matter columns appear intensely blue
Gray matter appears pink/pale (counterstain)
Useful for identifying demyelinating diseases
Motor neurons visible as large cells in gray matter
location: Cross-section of spinal cord at various levels
Demonstrates myelin distribution patterns
Anterior horns contain motor neurons
function: Histological demonstration of myelin
Diagnosis of demyelinating conditions
Study of white matter tract organization
theory.examTips: LFB is THE stain for myelin visualization. In MS and other demyelinating diseases, LFB shows pale areas where myelin is lost. Remember: LFB = Lipid-loving, stains myelin Blue. Often combined with H&E or Nissl counterstain.

medium: /slides/Central Nervous System/Spinal Cord/Spinal Cord (Ventral Horns)/Ventral Horns (LFB Stains)/10.-Spinal-cord-–-Ventral-horns-Medium-power-LFB-stain-1-1.png
/slides/Central Nervous System/Spinal Cord/Spinal Cord (Ventral Horns)/Ventral Horns (LFB Stains)/6.-Spinal-cord-–-Ventral-horns-Medium-power-LFB-stain-1.jpg
high: /slides/Central Nervous System/Spinal Cord/Spinal Cord (Ventral Horns)/Ventral Horns (LFB Stains)/12.-Spinal-cord-–-Ventral-horns-High-power-Luxol-fast-blue-1.jpg

name: Bronchus
description: Bronchi are conducting airways with walls containing cartilage plates, smooth muscle, and mucous glands. They are lined by pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium (respiratory epithelium).

features: Pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells
Irregular cartilage plates (vs C-shaped rings in trachea)
Spiral smooth muscle bands (muscle of Reissessen)
Submucosal seromucous glands
Fibroelastic connective tissue in lamina propria
location: Primary bronchi enter at hila of lungs
Branch into lobar and segmental bronchi
Within lung parenchyma
function: Conduct air to bronchioles
Mucociliary clearance of particles
Bronchoconstriction/dilation via smooth muscle
theory.examTips: Bronchi have cartilage and glands; bronchioles have neither. As airways branch: epithelium becomes simpler, cartilage disappears, smooth muscle increases proportionally. Asthma involves bronchial smooth muscle spasm and mucus hypersecretion.

name: Lung
description: Lung parenchyma consists of respiratory bronchioles, alveolar ducts, alveolar sacs, and alveoli. The alveoli are thin-walled air spaces for gas exchange, lined by Type I and II pneumocytes.

features: Alveoli: thin-walled air spaces for gas exchange
Type I pneumocytes: flat cells covering 95% of alveolar surface
Type II pneumocytes: cuboidal cells producing surfactant
Alveolar macrophages (dust cells) in alveolar spaces
Interalveolar septa with capillary network and elastic fibers
location: Thoracic cavity, paired organs
Right lung: 3 lobes; Left lung: 2 lobes
Base on diaphragm, apex extends above 1st rib
function: Gas exchange: O2/CO2 across blood-air barrier
Surfactant reduces surface tension, prevents atelectasis
Immune defense via alveolar macrophages
theory.examTips: Blood-air barrier = Type I pneumocyte + fused basement membranes + capillary endothelium (~0.5 μm thick). Type II pneumocytes produce surfactant and are progenitor cells. Surfactant appears at 24-28 weeks - premature babies risk RDS.

name: Trachea
description: The trachea is a fibromuscular tube reinforced by 16-20 C-shaped hyaline cartilage rings. It is lined by pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells (respiratory epithelium).

features: C-shaped hyaline cartilage rings (open posteriorly)
Pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells
Trachealis muscle spans posterior gap between cartilage ends
Submucosa with seromucous glands
Adventitia of fibroelastic connective tissue
location: C6 vertebra to T4-T5 (carina)
Anterior to esophagus
10-12 cm long, 2-2.5 cm diameter
function: Conducts air from larynx to bronchi
Mucociliary escalator clears debris
Warms, humidifies, and filters inspired air
theory.examTips: Trachealis muscle allows esophageal expansion during swallowing. Cilia beat toward pharynx (mucociliary escalator). Goblet cells + ciliated cells = respiratory epithelium. Kartagener syndrome: immotile cilia causing recurrent infections, situs inversus.
